title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: GitHub API
text: Use gh() function access API endpoints. endpoints listed documentation. first argument gh() endpoint. can just copy paste API endpoints documentation. Note leading slash must included well. https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#list-repositories---user can copy paste GET /users/{username}/repos gh() call. E.g. JSON result sent API converted R object. Parameters can passed extra arguments. E.g.
code: library(gh) my_repos <- gh("GET /users/{username}/repos", username = "gaborcsardi") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "alexr"        "altlist"      "argufy"       "disposables"  "dotenv"       #>  [6] "falsy"        "franc"        "ISA"          "keypress"     "lpSolve"      #> [11] "macBriain"    "maxygen"      "MISO"         "msgtools"     "notifier"     #> [16] "oskeyring"    "parr"         "parsedate"    "prompt"       "r-font"       #> [21] "r-source"     "rcorpora"     "roxygenlabs"  "sankey"       "secret"       #> [26] "spark"        "standalones"  "svg-term"     "tamper"       "testthatlabs" my_repos <- gh(   "/users/{username}/repos",   username = "gaborcsardi",   sort = "created") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "oskeyring"    "testthatlabs" "lpSolve"      "roxygenlabs"  "standalones"  #>  [6] "altlist"      "svg-term"     "franc"        "sankey"       "r-source"     #> [11] "secret"       "msgtools"     "notifier"     "prompt"       "parr"         #> [16] "tamper"       "alexr"        "argufy"       "maxygen"      "keypress"     #> [21] "macBriain"    "MISO"         "rcorpora"     "disposables"  "spark"        #> [26] "dotenv"       "parsedate"    "r-font"       "falsy"        "ISA"

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: extremely minimal client. need know API able use client. function : Try substitute listed parameter endpoint, using {parameter} notation. GET request (default), add listed parameters query parameters. GET request, send parameters request body, JSON. Convert response R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
code: gh(   endpoint,   ...,   per_page = NULL,   .token = NULL,   .destfile = NULL,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .api_url = NULL,   .method = "GET",   .limit = NULL,   .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",   .send_headers = NULL,   .progress = TRUE,   .params = list() )

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: endpoint GitHub API endpoint. Must one following forms: METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit, path, e.g. /rate_limit, METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit, url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit. method supplied, use .method, defaults "GET". ... Name-value pairs giving API parameters. matched endpoint placeholders, sent query parameters GET requests, JSON body POST requests. one unnamed parameter, raw vector, JSON encoded, sent raw data, . can used example add assets releases. Named NULL values silently dropped. GET requests, named NA values trigger error. methods, named NA values included body request, JSON null. per_page Number items return per page. omitted, substituted max(.limit, 100) .limit set, otherwise determined API (never greater 100). .token Authentication token. Defaults GITHUB_PAT GITHUB_TOKEN environment variables, order set. See gh_token() need flexibility, e.g. different tokens different GitHub Enterprise deployments. .destfile Path write response disk. NULL (default), response processed returned object. path given, response written disk form sent. .overwrite .destfile provided, whether overwrite existing file.  Defaults FALSE. .api_url Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used endpoint just contains path. Defaults GITHUB_API_URL environment variable set. .method HTTP method use explicitly supplied endpoint. .limit Number records return. can used instead manual pagination. default NULL, means defaults GitHub API used. can set number request (less) records, also Inf request records. Note, request many records, multiple GitHub API calls used get , can take potentially long time. .accept value Accept HTTP header. Defaults "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . Accept given .send_headers, used. parameter can used provide custom media type, order access preview feature API. .send_headers Named character vector header field values (except Authorization, handled via .token). can used override augment default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh". .progress Whether show progress indicator calls need one HTTP request. .params Additional list parameters append .... easier use ... parameters list already.

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: Answer API gh_response object, also list. Failed requests generate R error. Requests generate raw response return raw vector.

#>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I'm not sure if this counts as an issue but I came across an unexpected behaviour in na_if() in combination with is.nan() as seen below\r\n```\r\n#> library(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\n\r\n(df <- tibble::tribble(~var1, ~var2, ~var3,\r\n                        1, 0, NA_real_,\r\n                        0, 1, 0, \r\n                        1, 1, 1, \r\n                        NaN, 0, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     0    NA\r\n#> 2     0     1     0\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4   NaN     0     1\r\n\r\n# what I would have expected\r\ndf %>% \r\n  mutate(across(.fns = ~case_when(is.nan(.) ~ NA_real_, \r\n                                  TRUE ~ .)))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     0    NA\r\n#> 2     0     1     0\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4    NA     0     1\r\n\r\n\r\n# What I got is this unexpected result\r\n# with all '0's turned to NA and NaN still\r\n# being around\r\ndf %>% \r\n  mutate(across(.fns = ~na_if(., is.nan(.))))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1    NA    NA\r\n#> 2    NA     1    NA\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4   NaN    NA     1\r\n\r\n```\r\nI'm confused as `is.nan(0)` returns FALSE  - and I couldn't find in the documentation that it should not be used with NaN - what am I missing? \"am\"))))\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-04-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": use a named vector on the RHS of `case_when()`, it replaces the names with `NA`s. In the reprex below, I would expect the returned vector to be identical to `x`.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nx <- `names<-`(1:3, letters[1:3])\r\nx\r\n#> a b c \r\n#> 1 2 3\r\n\r\ncase_when(T ~ x)\r\n#> <NA> <NA> <NA> \r\n#>    1    2    3\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-03-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n<details #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Hello, \r\nI'm wrangling an audio dataset that will be used for classification with torch. For that, \"chopping\" the dataset into segments is a useful thing to do (maybe there are more use cases). Wondering if anyone would be interested in implementing a dplyr function to accomplish this, which is just a repeated slicing of a given tibble. \r\n\r\nHere's the function I came up with:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\n\r\n#' @title \"Chop\" data into segments. \r\n#' @description Iteratively slice (chop) a dataset into segments (sub-datasets)\r\n#'  of predefined length. \r\n#' @return `output` list containing each segment sub-dataset.  \r\n#' @param dataset, dataset to be \"chopped\"\r\n#' @param nrow_per_segment, predefined N of rows of each segment\r\n#' @param keep_remaining, logical indicating if remaining rows of `dataset` are\r\n#'   to be kept, in the case where the number of segments is not a whole number.\r\n#'   If TRUE (default), the last segment will contain the remaining rows. If \r\n#'   FALSE, remaining rows will be dropped. \r\n\r\n\r\nchop_data <- function(\r\n  dataset, \r\n  nrow_per_segment, \r\n  keep_remaining = TRUE \r\n) {\r\n  \r\n  n_segments <- nrow(dataset) / nrow_per_segment\r\n  n_segments_floor <- floor(n_segments)\r\n  \r\n  output <- list()   \r\n  for (i in 1:n_segments_floor) {\r\n    segment_head <- ((i - 1) * nrow_per_segment + 1)\r\n    segment_tail <- (i * nrow_per_segment)\r\n    \r\n    output[[i]] <-  dataset %>%  \r\n      slice(segment_head:segment_tail)\r\n    \r\n  }\r\n  \r\n  print(\r\n    paste0(\r\n      \"chopped dataset into \", \r\n      n_segments_floor, \r\n      \" segments\"\r\n    )\r\n  )\r\n  \r\n  if (keep_remaining == TRUE) {\r\n    output[[i + 1]] <- dataset %>% \r\n      slice(segment_tail:nrow(dataset))\r\n    \r\n    print(\r\n      paste0(\r\n        \"Kept remaining rows inside an extra \", \r\n        nrow(output[[i + 1]]),\r\n        \" row segment\"\r\n      )\r\n    )\r\n  } \r\n  \r\n  \r\n  return(output)\r\n   \r\n}\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe function's result can be checked by running\r\n```{r}\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\nexample <- chop_data(\r\n  dataset = mpg, \r\n  nrow_per_segment = 20,\r\n  keep_remaining = TRUE\r\n)\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nCheers", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "created_at": "2022-03-20T09:17:30Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-03-20T09:24:54Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Sometimes we may think `group_df` is like a unified but separate ~~data.frame~~ (like a `list-data.frame`), where we mistake to change factor levels in the different group of this data. \r\n\r\nThere're some questions in `stackoverflow`:\r\n-https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57696639/reorder-factor-levels-within-group\r\n-https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53698444/reorder-factor-not-working-on-grouped-data\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\ndf <- tibble::tibble(\r\n    afct = factor(rep(c(\"f1\", \"f2\"), times = 2), levels = c(\"f1\", \"f2\")),\r\n    group = rep(c(\"a\", \"b\"), each = 2),\r\n    weight = c(1, 2, 2, 1)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# we mistate to do this:\r\ndf %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_by(group) %>%\r\n    dplyr::mutate(\r\n        bfct = forcats::fct_reorder(afct, weight)\r\n    ) %>%\r\n    dplyr::pull(bfct)\r\n#> [1] f1 f2 f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f1 f2\r\n\r\n# what we need is like this: \r\ndf %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_by(group) %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_split() %>%\r\n    lapply(function(x) {\r\n        x %>%\r\n            dplyr::mutate(\r\n                bfct = forcats::fct_reorder(afct, weight)\r\n            ) %>%\r\n            dplyr::pull(bfct)\r\n    })\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#> [1] f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f1 f2\r\n#> \r\n#> [[2]]\r\n#> [1] f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f2 f1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-03-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6216/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #> "_Edit:_ Updated to reflect @DavisVaughan's suggestion [here](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6214#issuecomment-1069226334)\r\n\r\nNot sure on the name, but any thoughts on implementing a `.groups` arg so that functions can operate by group without returning a `grouped_df`?\r\n\r\nBasically this:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf <- tibble(x = 1:3, y = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\"))\r\n\r\ndf %>%\r\n  mutate(pct = x/sum(x), .groups = y)\r\n```\r\n\r\nwould be equivalent to this:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf %>%\r\n  group_by(y) %>%\r\n  mutate(pct = x/sum(x)) %>%\r\n  ungroup()\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe name `.groups` might not work since it already exists in summarize() for a different purpose (though still marked as experimental). `.group_by` also might be slightly confusing since it would operate differently than `group_by()`.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6214/reactions", #>       "total_count": 3, #>       "+1": 3, #>       "-1": #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "---\r\nI would like to humbly suggest the following feature, totally aware that you cannot design functions to everyones needs:\r\n\r\nsample_n used to support size-arguments that differ across groups. slice_sample does not. In usecases for at least three organisations I found this feature quite useful, as taking stratified samples with varying sample-sizes was often required. This keeps me from adapting to the new slice_sample. Would you kindly consider adding this feature to slice_sample?\r\nThank you very much!\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(palmerpenguins)\r\n\r\n# currently not supported:\r\npenguins %>% \r\n  mutate(n_samples = case_when(\r\n    year == 2007 ~ 3L,\r\n    year == 2008 ~ 2L,\r\n    year == 2009 ~ 4L,\r\n    TRUE ~ 0L\r\n  )) %>% \r\n  group_by(year) %>%\r\n   slice_sample(n = n_samples) # formerly sample_n(size = n_samples)\r\n```\r\nError in `check_constant()`:\r\n! `n` must be a constant in `slice_sample()`", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>       } #>     ], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2022-03-07T15:57:36Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-04-01T00:32:20Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Currently, `relocate()` relies on the fact that `vec_unique()` keeps names\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/8abb54b60e40ef7c619156a12b14872cb2eb7989/R/relocate.R#L83-L85\r\n\r\nWe think we should actually drop names from the result of `vec_unique()`, since the returned names are reliant on the fact that only the _first_ encountered duplicate value is returned (this is also consistent with `unique()`). See https://github.com/r-lib/vctrs/issues/1442 and https://github.com/r-lib/vctrs/pull/1532 where we tried to implement this, but found that dplyr relies on this behavior currently.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nOne easy way to fix this is to use `vec_unique_loc()` to get the locations, and then `vec_slice()`, which will retain names.\r\n\r\nThat should work in the immediate term but it may be worth looking at the code to also see why we currently get names off the unique values, and if there is something else we should be doing instead, since that _feels_ unreliable.", #> "created_at": "2022-03-04T12:39:16Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-04-04T20:15:57Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "It seems that since recently mutate `case_when()` calls are more strictly evaluated with regard to the variable type (or it always was as strict and some other R or package update, now produces integer instead of double values). \r\nThat's fine, but I think, ideally the error message would be more informative than `'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]`, especially for this borderline case where (depending on the data) the same code might produce either integers or doubles.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attache Paket: 'dplyr'\r\n#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\nlibrary(magrittr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = c(\"yes\", \"no\"), \r\n       b = as.integer(c(0,2))) %>% \r\n  mutate(b = case_when(a == \"yes\" ~ NA_real_, \r\n                       TRUE ~ b))\r\n#> Error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `b = case_when(a == \"yes\" ~ NA_real_, TRUE ~\r\n#>   b)`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `names(message) <- `*vtmp*``:\r\n#> ! Attribut 'names' [1] muss dieselbe Länge haben wie der Vektor [0]\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-03-04 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n<details #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I've found the documentation for across() about the multiple function case more oblique than perhaps it could be, but I'm not familiar enough with all of its applications to be sure I'll get it right if I directly submit a change via pull. This applies to both the Roxygen comment on R/across.R and to a lesser degree the colwise vignette, vignettes/colwise.Rmd\r\n\r\nThe current text in the Roxygen comment is\r\n>Functions to apply to each of the selected columns. Possible values are:\r\n>    - NULL, to returns the columns untransformed.\r\n>    - A function, e.g. mean.\r\n>    - A purrr-style lambda, e.g. ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE)\r\n>    - A list of functions/lambdas, e.g. list(mean = mean, n_miss = ~ sum(is.na(.x))\r\n\r\nand in the vignette,\r\n\r\n> The second argument, .fns, is a function or list of functions to apply to each column. This can also be a purrr style formula (or list of formulas) like ~ .x / 2. (This argument is optional, and you can omit it if you just want to get the underlying data; you’ll see that technique used in vignette(\"rowwise\").)\r\n> ...\r\n> ### Multiple functions\r\n>\r\n> You can transform each variable with more than one function by supplying a named list of functions or lambda functions in the second argument:\r\n\r\nThe intuition that I'm only seeing referred to indirectly is that the provided functions *fan out* into multiple outputs, i.e. if you provided n columns and m functions you'd end up with n x m outputs. The Roxygen intro also refers to transformation in the singular, \"across() makes it easy to apply the same transformation to multiple columns...\", so it feels like the multiple-output case is de-emphasised. There are other possible interpretations for \"Functions to apply to each of the selected columns\", e.g. maybe the functions are applied in order, to a single output. (This is of course very achievable through other methods like `purrr::compose` or `. %>% ...` pipes or purrr lambdas, and not necessary for `across` to do, but it's not ruled out by the description.)\r\n\r\nIt's also not made entirely clear that an _unnamed_ list of functions `c(...)` is probably unusual, i.e. the reason a _named_ list is used is because the name determines the output name (depending on `.names`) - someone might use an unnamed list in an ad-hoc to test a range of transformations, but named lists match the intention behind the design of the function better. The vignette is clearer about this, and while Roxygen uses a named list as an example but leaves the choice unaddressed, i.e. it could just be a code style cue to make a lambda more readable. (I've primarily used across with `mutate`, so the rationale in the `summarise`-style example wasn't immediately obvious.)\r\n\r\nMy suggestion would be to emphasise that a separate output is produced for each function, e.g. a maybe clumsy alternative wording would be\r\n> Functions to apply to each of the selected columns, where each transformation produces a separate output column based on the column and list names.\r\n\r\nAgain, I don't know for sure if this conflicts with any current or planned uses for the function. As far as I can tell across more or less enforces this as a constraint, i.e. requires unique names for each output (although of course transform functions can return NULL in order to _not_ produce a new output column. _Optionally_ producing output for a list of functions opens up some interesting variations I guess that vary a little from the n x m account.)\r\n\r\nMostly my sense was that the intention or purpose behind the argument was underspecified in the documentation, making it harder to understand the behaviour unless you already know the behaviour. Partly this could be a consequence of across being a fairly flexible tool so its 'meaning' can look a little different in different uses, but I think we can nudge the docs towards giving a quicker birds-eye view. Hopefully you can see where I'm coming from.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6205/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/feature", #>         "name": "feature", #>         "color": "B4C3AE", #>         "default": false, #>         "description": "a feature request or enhancement" #>       } #>     ], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2022-03-03T12:58:41Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-03-03T17:26:06Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Would it be useful to have a dedicated function (say, `pick()`) to select columns from the current data? Currently, `across()` with only a `.cols` argument serves this role.\r\n\r\nI would see a dedicated function having at least three advantages:\r\n\r\n1.  Nicer syntax for union selections: `pick(1, last_col())` vs. `across(c(1, last_col()))`.\r\n2.  Better semantics. `across()` makes sense when there’s functions to apply, but less so when it’s used just for selecting columns. `pick()` seems intuitive for only selecting columns.\r\n3.  Reuse existing patterns: `across(c(1:2, 4), mean)` vs. `map_df(pick(1:2, 4), mean)`. The first requires you to know that `across()` can select columns *and* apply a function, latter can re-use existing function application methods.\r\n\r\nThe last point is particularly important if/when `...` is deprecated in `across()` (\\#6073), as funtionality would not be identical anymore. For example:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# With no ..., need to use an anonymous function for na.rm\r\nacross(c(1, 3:4), ~ mean(., na.rm = TRUE))\r\n\r\n# Could be avoided with `pick()`\r\nmap_df(pick(1, 3:4), mean, na.rm = TRUE)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI would see the primary uses for this as:\r\n\r\n1.  Replace `across()` in e.g. `group_by()` selections `group_by(across(c(1, 3:5)))` vs. `group_by(pick(1, 3:5))`. Big semantic and syntactic win, IMO.\r\n2.  Passing arguments to functions that take data frame or matrix arguments. For example common questions about taking means or sums over rows in data frames. In my experience people don’t think to `apply(across(1:5), 1, f)`, but `apply(pick(1:5), 1, f)` might be more intuitive.\r\n\r\nI could think of two ways to implement this as a wrapper:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\npick <- function(...) {\r\n  across(.cols = c(...))\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nOr:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\npick <- function(...) {\r\n  select(cur_data(), ...)\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nAlthough, particularly with the `across()` route, it would seem nicer to reverse the dependency and extract the relevant parts from `across()` into`pick()` instead.\r\n\r\nI appreciate your consideration for this feature request.\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6204/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #>    "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203", #>       "diff_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203.diff", #>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203.patch", #>       "merged_at": {} #>     }, #>     "body": "Follow-up to #6199 and continuation of the plan from here https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5588#issuecomment-1048373544\r\n\r\nCloses #5984 \r\nCloses #5699 \r\n\r\nThis PR adds a new `conflict` argument to `rows_insert()`, `rows_update()`, `rows_patch()`, and `rows_delete()`, inspired by the `ON CONFLICT *` command from SQL's `INSERT`.\r\n\r\n- For `rows_insert()`, a conflict arises if there is a key in `y` that _already_ exists in `x`. By default, it `\"error\"`s, but you can now also `\"ignore\"` the rows in `y` where this occurs, which is like `ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING`.\r\n\r\n- For `rows_update()`, `rows_patch()`, and `rows_delete()`, a conflict arises if there is a key in `y` that _doesn't_ exist in `x` (because the behavior is then ambiguous). Again, by default it `\"error\"`s, but you can also `\"ignore\"` those rows in `y`.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nA few more notes:\r\n\r\n- `conflict` is a bit of a non-standard name for the update/patch/delete behavior, but I think it works well enough. The alternative was to use `conflict` for `rows_insert()` and come up with some other argument name for these 3. Or use `matched` for insert and `unmatched` for update/patch/delete. I am open to suggestions if anyone feels strongly against the current scheme.\r\n\r\n- In https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5588#issuecomment-1025599455, @mgirlich mentioned the possibility of `rows_insert(conflict = \"insert\")` to insert the `y` rows anyways even if there are conflicts, but this felt too similar to `bind_rows()` to me, so I left it out (i.e. it would always insert the `y` rows, no matter what, which is basically just binding the rows together after validating that the `by` columns exist in both inputs). I think we could consider adding it later if people ask for it.\r\n\r\n- I've used a default of `\"error\"` because that is what the current behavior is, and it feels reasonable to opt in to this more lax behavior.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6203/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #> "body": "See below for a reprex for selecting a column that doesn't exist:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(x = 1:2, y = 3:4)\r\ndf\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 2\r\n#>       x     y\r\n#>   <int> <int>\r\n#> 1     1     3\r\n#> 2     2     4\r\ndf %>% select(z)\r\n#> Error in `stop_subscript()`:\r\n#> ! Can't subset columns that don't exist.\r\n#> x Column `z` doesn't exist.\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-02-27 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI think the error should say `Can't select columns that don't exist` since `subset` is not the verb used in the code, and it actually means `filter()` in base R.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Not entirely sure if I just don't find it, but `slice_sample` does not support sampling from the unique values of a column (like the `sample` function would do).\n\nLet's assume I have the following data and would want to randomly filter the data on 2 of the 5 unique x values.\n\n```\ndf <- data.frame(x = rep(1:5, 3))\n\n# works\nlibrary(tidyverse)\ndf %>%\n  filter(x %in% sample(unique(x), size = 2, replace = FALSE))\n\n# does not work\ndf %>%\n  slice_sample(???)\n```", #> #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "mutate + recode on a character column is much slower (40x) than the same operation on a factor column,\r\neven compared to as.character(recode(factor(...),....)) \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(microbenchmark)\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\nl50 <- c(letters[1:25], LETTERS[1:25])\r\nn <- 1000000\r\n\r\nat <- tibble(\r\n  id  = seq(1, n),\r\n  str = rep(l50, n/50)\r\n)\r\n\r\nrecode_list <- as.list(setNames(str_c(\"xxx\", l50), l50))\r\n\r\nmicrobenchmark(\r\n  recode_char     = at %>% mutate(str = recode(str, !!!recode_list)),\r\n  recode_fct      = at %>% mutate(str = recode(factor(str), !!!recode_list)),\r\n  recode_fct_char = at %>% mutate(str = as.character(recode(factor(str), !!!recode_list))),\r\n  times = 10\r\n)\r\n```\r\n![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17407796/155575938-2eaee285-c425-404d-9eea-710096a9a70f.png)", #>     "reactions": { #> #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Say I have a list filter functions that I want to run against a data frame. A natural way to do this would be to use `filter(if_all(...))`. This gives an error when you invoke `cur_column()` inside `if_all(...)`.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\ncriteria <- list(\r\n    Species = \\(.x) paste(.x) < \"v\",\r\n    Petal.Width = \\(.x) .x < .3\r\n)\r\n\r\n# Error: cur_column() demands to be called inside across()\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    )\r\n#> Error in `filter()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = criteria[[cur_column()]](Species) &\r\n#>   ...`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `cur_column()`:\r\n#> ! Must be used inside `across()`.\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever, if I simply add extra parentheses around the `if_all(...)`, everything works:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# OK: extra parens around (if_all(...cur_column()...))\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        (if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        ))\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf I use `across(...)` instead of `if_all(...)`, it works without extra parentheses but this is deprecated. Fixing the warning was how I discovered this issue.\r\n\r\n----\r\nFull reprex.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\n\r\ncriteria <- list(\r\n    Species = \\(.x) paste(.x) < \"v\",\r\n    Petal.Width = \\(.x) .x < .3\r\n)\r\n\r\n# Error: cur_column() demands to be called inside across()\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    )\r\n#> Error in `filter()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = criteria[[cur_column()]](Species) &\r\n#>   ...`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `cur_column()`:\r\n#> ! Must be used inside `across()`.\r\n\r\n# OK: extra parens around (if_all(...cur_column()...))\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        (if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        ))\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n\r\n# OK but deprecated\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        across(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Warning: Using `across()` in `filter()` is deprecated, use `if_any()` or\r\n#> `if_all()`.\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n\r\nsessionInfo()\r\n#> R version 4.1.2 (2021-11-01)\r\n#> Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)\r\n#> Running under: Windows 10 x64 (build 19043)\r\n#> \r\n#> Matrix products: default\r\n#> \r\n#> locale:\r\n#> [1] LC_COLLATE=English_Australia.1252  LC_CTYPE=English_Australia.1252   \r\n#> [3] LC_MONETARY=English_Australia.1252 LC_NUMERIC=C                      \r\n#> [5] LC_TIME=English_Australia.1252    \r\n#> \r\n#> attached base packages:\r\n#> [1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n#> \r\n#> other attached packages:\r\n#> [1] dplyr_1.0.8\r\n#> \r\n#> loaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n#>  [1] pillar_1.7.0      compiler_4.1.2    highr_0.9         R.methodsS3_1.8.1\r\n#>  [5] R.utils_2.11.0    tools_4.1.2       digest_0.6.29     evaluate_0.15    \r\n#>  [9] lifecycle_1.0.1   tibble_3.1.6      R.cache_0.15.0    pkgconfig_2.0.3  \r\n#> [13] rlang_1.0.1       reprex_2.0.1      DBI_1.1.2         cli_3.1.1        \r\n#> [17] rstudioapi_0.13   yaml_2.2.2        xfun_0.29         fastmap_1.1.0    \r\n#> [21] withr_2.4.3       styler_1.6.2      stringr_1.4.0     knitr_1.37       \r\n#> [25] generics_0.1.2    fs_1.5.2          vctrs_0.3.8       tidyselect_1.1.1 \r\n#> [29] glue_1.6.1        R6_2.5.1          fansi_1.0.2       rmarkdown_2.11   \r\n#> [33] purrr_0.3.4       magrittr_2.0.2 programming with `dplyr`, it can be handy to pass `NULL` as a value.\r\n\r\nFor instance when using `group_by()`, I can pass `NULL` when I want to use my custom function but I don't want to group on any variable.\r\n\r\nHowever, while `group_by()` allow this syntax, `arrange()` throws an unexpected error:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\ndplyr::group_by(iris, NULL)[1,]\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 5\r\n#>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species\r\n#>          <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> <fct>  \r\n#> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 setosa\r\ndplyr::arrange(iris, "2022-02-15T13:46:34Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-02-15T13:46:34Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "When using a `mutate()` statement on a grouped dataframe, using the `!!` operator for a constant of an appropriate length greater than 1 throws an error in version 1.0.8, but, not using the `!!` operator works.  This is a break from previous versions.\r\n\r\nI first noticed the break moving from version 1.0.7 to 1.0.8, and, it appears it is still happening in the 1.0.8.9000.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.2'\r\n\r\ny <- c(1, 2)\r\n\r\n# works with y and !!y\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = y)\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 2\r\n#> # Groups:   x [2]\r\n#>   x     numbers\r\n#>   <chr>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1 a           1\r\n#> 2 a           2\r\n#> 3 b           1\r\n#> 4 b           2\r\n\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = !!y)\r\n#> # with is.nan() as seen below\r\n```\r\n#> library(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\n\r\n(df <- tibble::tribble(~var1, ~var2, ~var3,\r\n                        1, 0, NA_real_,\r\n                        0, 1, 0, \r\n                        1, 1, 1, \r\n                        NaN, 0, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     0    NA\r\n#> 2     0     1     0\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4   NaN     0     1\r\n\r\n# what I would have expected\r\ndf %>% \r\n  mutate(across(.fns = ~case_when(is.nan(.) ~ NA_real_, \r\n                                  TRUE ~ .)))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     0    NA\r\n#> 2     0     1     0\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4    NA     0     1\r\n\r\n\r\n# What I got is this unexpected result\r\n# with all '0's turned to NA and NaN still\r\n# being around\r\ndf %>% \r\n  mutate(across(.fns = ~na_if(., is.nan(.))))\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 3\r\n#>    var1  var2  var3\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1    NA    NA\r\n#> 2    NA     1    NA\r\n#> 3     1     1     1\r\n#> 4   NaN    NA     1\r\n\r\n```\r\nI'm confused as `is.nan(0)` returns FALSE  - and I couldn't find in the documentation that it should not be used with NaN - what am I missing? #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Hello, \r\nI'm wrangling an audio dataset that will be used for classification with torch. For that, \"chopping\" the dataset into segments is a useful thing to do (maybe there are more use cases). Wondering if anyone would be interested in implementing a dplyr function to accomplish this, which is just a repeated slicing of a given tibble. \r\n\r\nHere's the function I came up with:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\n\r\n#' @title \"Chop\" data into segments. \r\n#' @description Iteratively slice (chop) a dataset into segments (sub-datasets)\r\n#'  of predefined length. \r\n#' @return `output` list containing each segment sub-dataset.  \r\n#' @param dataset, dataset to be \"chopped\"\r\n#' @param nrow_per_segment, predefined N of rows of each segment\r\n#' @param keep_remaining, logical indicating if remaining rows of `dataset` are\r\n#'   to be kept, in the case where the number of segments is not a whole number.\r\n#'   If TRUE (default), the last segment will contain the remaining rows. If \r\n#'   FALSE, remaining rows will be dropped. \r\n\r\n\r\nchop_data <- function(\r\n  dataset, \r\n  nrow_per_segment, \r\n  keep_remaining = TRUE \r\n) {\r\n  \r\n  n_segments <- nrow(dataset) / nrow_per_segment\r\n  n_segments_floor <- floor(n_segments)\r\n  \r\n  output <- list()   \r\n  for (i in 1:n_segments_floor) {\r\n    segment_head <- ((i - 1) * nrow_per_segment + 1)\r\n    segment_tail <- (i * nrow_per_segment)\r\n    \r\n    output[[i]] <-  dataset %>%  \r\n      slice(segment_head:segment_tail)\r\n    \r\n  }\r\n  \r\n  print(\r\n    paste0(\r\n      \"chopped dataset into \", \r\n      n_segments_floor, \r\n      \" segments\"\r\n    )\r\n  )\r\n  \r\n  if (keep_remaining == TRUE) {\r\n    output[[i + 1]] <- dataset %>% \r\n      slice(segment_tail:nrow(dataset))\r\n    \r\n    print(\r\n      paste0(\r\n        \"Kept remaining rows inside an extra \", \r\n        nrow(output[[i + 1]]),\r\n        \" row segment\"\r\n      )\r\n    )\r\n  } \r\n  \r\n  \r\n  return(output)\r\n   \r\n}\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe function's result can be checked by running\r\n```{r}\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\nexample <- chop_data(\r\n  dataset = mpg, \r\n  nrow_per_segment = 20,\r\n  keep_remaining = TRUE\r\n)\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nCheers", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "created_at": "2022-03-20T09:17:30Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-03-20T09:24:54Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Sometimes we may think `group_df` is like a unified but separate ~~data.frame~~ (like a `list-data.frame`), where we mistake to change factor levels in the different group of this data. \r\n\r\nThere're some questions in `stackoverflow`:\r\n-https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57696639/reorder-factor-levels-within-group\r\n-https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53698444/reorder-factor-not-working-on-grouped-data\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\ndf <- tibble::tibble(\r\n    afct = factor(rep(c(\"f1\", \"f2\"), times = 2), levels = c(\"f1\", \"f2\")),\r\n    group = rep(c(\"a\", \"b\"), each = 2),\r\n    weight = c(1, 2, 2, 1)\r\n)\r\n\r\n# we mistate to do this:\r\ndf %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_by(group) %>%\r\n    dplyr::mutate(\r\n        bfct = forcats::fct_reorder(afct, weight)\r\n    ) %>%\r\n    dplyr::pull(bfct)\r\n#> [1] f1 f2 f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f1 f2\r\n\r\n# what we need is like this: \r\ndf %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_by(group) %>%\r\n    dplyr::group_split() %>%\r\n    lapply(function(x) {\r\n        x %>%\r\n            dplyr::mutate(\r\n                bfct = forcats::fct_reorder(afct, weight)\r\n            ) %>%\r\n            dplyr::pull(bfct)\r\n    })\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#> [1] f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f1 f2\r\n#> \r\n#> [[2]]\r\n#> [1] f1 f2\r\n#> Levels: f2 f1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-03-20 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6216/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #> "_Edit:_ Updated to reflect @DavisVaughan's suggestion [here](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6214#issuecomment-1069226334)\r\n\r\nNot sure on the name, but any thoughts on implementing a `.groups` arg so that functions can operate by group without returning a `grouped_df`?\r\n\r\nBasically this:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf <- tibble(x = 1:3, y = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\"))\r\n\r\ndf %>%\r\n  mutate(pct = x/sum(x), .groups = y)\r\n```\r\n\r\nwould be equivalent to this:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf %>%\r\n  group_by(y) %>%\r\n  mutate(pct = x/sum(x)) %>%\r\n  ungroup()\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe name `.groups` might not work since it already exists in summarize() for a different purpose (though still marked as experimental). `.group_by` also might be slightly confusing since it would operate differently than `group_by()`.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6214/reactions", #>       "total_count": 3, #>       "+1": 3, #>       "-1": #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "---\r\nI would like to humbly suggest the following feature, totally aware that you cannot design functions to everyones needs:\r\n\r\nsample_n used to support size-arguments that differ across groups. slice_sample does not. In usecases for at least three organisations I found this feature quite useful, as taking stratified samples with varying sample-sizes was often required. This keeps me from adapting to the new slice_sample. Would you kindly consider adding this feature to slice_sample?\r\nThank you very much!\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(palmerpenguins)\r\n\r\n# currently not supported:\r\npenguins %>% \r\n  mutate(n_samples = case_when(\r\n    year == 2007 ~ 3L,\r\n    year == 2008 ~ 2L,\r\n    year == 2009 ~ 4L,\r\n    TRUE ~ 0L\r\n  )) %>% \r\n  group_by(year) %>%\r\n   slice_sample(n = n_samples) # formerly sample_n(size = n_samples)\r\n```\r\nError in `check_constant()`:\r\n! `n` must be a constant in `slice_sample()`", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>       } #>     ], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2022-03-07T15:57:36Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-04-01T00:32:20Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Currently, `relocate()` relies on the fact that `vec_unique()` keeps names\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/8abb54b60e40ef7c619156a12b14872cb2eb7989/R/relocate.R#L83-L85\r\n\r\nWe think we should actually drop names from the result of `vec_unique()`, since the returned names are reliant on the fact that only the _first_ encountered duplicate value is returned (this is also consistent with `unique()`). See https://github.com/r-lib/vctrs/issues/1442 and https://github.com/r-lib/vctrs/pull/1532 where we tried to implement this, but found that dplyr relies on this behavior currently.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nOne easy way to fix this is to use `vec_unique_loc()` to get the locations, and then `vec_slice()`, which will retain names.\r\n\r\nThat should work in the immediate term but it may be worth looking at the code to also see why we currently get names off the unique values, and if there is something else we should be doing instead, since that _feels_ unreliable.", #> "created_at": "2022-03-04T12:39:16Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-04-04T20:15:57Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "It seems that since recently mutate `case_when()` calls are more strictly evaluated with regard to the variable type (or it always was as strict and some other R or package update, now produces integer instead of double values). \r\nThat's fine, but I think, ideally the error message would be more informative than `'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]`, especially for this borderline case where (depending on the data) the same code might produce either integers or doubles.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attache Paket: 'dplyr'\r\n#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\nlibrary(magrittr)\r\n\r\ntibble(a = c(\"yes\", \"no\"), \r\n       b = as.integer(c(0,2))) %>% \r\n  mutate(b = case_when(a == \"yes\" ~ NA_real_, \r\n                       TRUE ~ b))\r\n#> Error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `b = case_when(a == \"yes\" ~ NA_real_, TRUE ~\r\n#>   b)`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `names(message) <- `*vtmp*``:\r\n#> ! Attribut 'names' [1] muss dieselbe Länge haben wie der Vektor [0]\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-03-04 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n<details #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I've found the documentation for across() about the multiple function case more oblique than perhaps it could be, but I'm not familiar enough with all of its applications to be sure I'll get it right if I directly submit a change via pull. This applies to both the Roxygen comment on R/across.R and to a lesser degree the colwise vignette, vignettes/colwise.Rmd\r\n\r\nThe current text in the Roxygen comment is\r\n>Functions to apply to each of the selected columns. Possible values are:\r\n>    - NULL, to returns the columns untransformed.\r\n>    - A function, e.g. mean.\r\n>    - A purrr-style lambda, e.g. ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE)\r\n>    - A list of functions/lambdas, e.g. list(mean = mean, n_miss = ~ sum(is.na(.x))\r\n\r\nand in the vignette,\r\n\r\n> The second argument, .fns, is a function or list of functions to apply to each column. This can also be a purrr style formula (or list of formulas) like ~ .x / 2. (This argument is optional, and you can omit it if you just want to get the underlying data; you’ll see that technique used in vignette(\"rowwise\").)\r\n> ...\r\n> ### Multiple functions\r\n>\r\n> You can transform each variable with more than one function by supplying a named list of functions or lambda functions in the second argument:\r\n\r\nThe intuition that I'm only seeing referred to indirectly is that the provided functions *fan out* into multiple outputs, i.e. if you provided n columns and m functions you'd end up with n x m outputs. The Roxygen intro also refers to transformation in the singular, \"across() makes it easy to apply the same transformation to multiple columns...\", so it feels like the multiple-output case is de-emphasised. There are other possible interpretations for \"Functions to apply to each of the selected columns\", e.g. maybe the functions are applied in order, to a single output. (This is of course very achievable through other methods like `purrr::compose` or `. %>% ...` pipes or purrr lambdas, and not necessary for `across` to do, but it's not ruled out by the description.)\r\n\r\nIt's also not made entirely clear that an _unnamed_ list of functions `c(...)` is probably unusual, i.e. the reason a _named_ list is used is because the name determines the output name (depending on `.names`) - someone might use an unnamed list in an ad-hoc to test a range of transformations, but named lists match the intention behind the design of the function better. The vignette is clearer about this, and while Roxygen uses a named list as an example but leaves the choice unaddressed, i.e. it could just be a code style cue to make a lambda more readable. (I've primarily used across with `mutate`, so the rationale in the `summarise`-style example wasn't immediately obvious.)\r\n\r\nMy suggestion would be to emphasise that a separate output is produced for each function, e.g. a maybe clumsy alternative wording would be\r\n> Functions to apply to each of the selected columns, where each transformation produces a separate output column based on the column and list names.\r\n\r\nAgain, I don't know for sure if this conflicts with any current or planned uses for the function. As far as I can tell across more or less enforces this as a constraint, i.e. requires unique names for each output (although of course transform functions can return NULL in order to _not_ produce a new output column. _Optionally_ producing output for a list of functions opens up some interesting variations I guess that vary a little from the n x m account.)\r\n\r\nMostly my sense was that the intention or purpose behind the argument was underspecified in the documentation, making it harder to understand the behaviour unless you already know the behaviour. Partly this could be a consequence of across being a fairly flexible tool so its 'meaning' can look a little different in different uses, but I think we can nudge the docs towards giving a quicker birds-eye view. Hopefully you can see where I'm coming from.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6205/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/feature", #>         "name": "feature", #>         "color": "B4C3AE", #>         "default": false, #>         "description": "a feature request or enhancement" #>       } #>     ], #>     "state": "open", #>     "locked": false, #>     "assignee": {}, #>     "assignees": [], #>     "milestone": {}, #>     "comments": 1, #>     "created_at": "2022-03-03T12:58:41Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-03-03T17:26:06Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Would it be useful to have a dedicated function (say, `pick()`) to select columns from the current data? Currently, `across()` with only a `.cols` argument serves this role.\r\n\r\nI would see a dedicated function having at least three advantages:\r\n\r\n1.  Nicer syntax for union selections: `pick(1, last_col())` vs. `across(c(1, last_col()))`.\r\n2.  Better semantics. `across()` makes sense when there’s functions to apply, but less so when it’s used just for selecting columns. `pick()` seems intuitive for only selecting columns.\r\n3.  Reuse existing patterns: `across(c(1:2, 4), mean)` vs. `map_df(pick(1:2, 4), mean)`. The first requires you to know that `across()` can select columns *and* apply a function, latter can re-use existing function application methods.\r\n\r\nThe last point is particularly important if/when `...` is deprecated in `across()` (\\#6073), as funtionality would not be identical anymore. For example:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# With no ..., need to use an anonymous function for na.rm\r\nacross(c(1, 3:4), ~ mean(., na.rm = TRUE))\r\n\r\n# Could be avoided with `pick()`\r\nmap_df(pick(1, 3:4), mean, na.rm = TRUE)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI would see the primary uses for this as:\r\n\r\n1.  Replace `across()` in e.g. `group_by()` selections `group_by(across(c(1, 3:5)))` vs. `group_by(pick(1, 3:5))`. Big semantic and syntactic win, IMO.\r\n2.  Passing arguments to functions that take data frame or matrix arguments. For example common questions about taking means or sums over rows in data frames. In my experience people don’t think to `apply(across(1:5), 1, f)`, but `apply(pick(1:5), 1, f)` might be more intuitive.\r\n\r\nI could think of two ways to implement this as a wrapper:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\npick <- function(...) {\r\n  across(.cols = c(...))\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nOr:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\npick <- function(...) {\r\n  select(cur_data(), ...)\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nAlthough, particularly with the `across()` route, it would seem nicer to reverse the dependency and extract the relevant parts from `across()` into`pick()` instead.\r\n\r\nI appreciate your consideration for this feature request.\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6204/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #>    "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203", #>       "diff_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203.diff", #>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6203.patch", #>       "merged_at": {} #>     }, #>     "body": "Follow-up to #6199 and continuation of the plan from here https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5588#issuecomment-1048373544\r\n\r\nCloses #5984 \r\nCloses #5699 \r\n\r\nThis PR adds a new `conflict` argument to `rows_insert()`, `rows_update()`, `rows_patch()`, and `rows_delete()`, inspired by the `ON CONFLICT *` command from SQL's `INSERT`.\r\n\r\n- For `rows_insert()`, a conflict arises if there is a key in `y` that _already_ exists in `x`. By default, it `\"error\"`s, but you can now also `\"ignore\"` the rows in `y` where this occurs, which is like `ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING`.\r\n\r\n- For `rows_update()`, `rows_patch()`, and `rows_delete()`, a conflict arises if there is a key in `y` that _doesn't_ exist in `x` (because the behavior is then ambiguous). Again, by default it `\"error\"`s, but you can also `\"ignore\"` those rows in `y`.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nA few more notes:\r\n\r\n- `conflict` is a bit of a non-standard name for the update/patch/delete behavior, but I think it works well enough. The alternative was to use `conflict` for `rows_insert()` and come up with some other argument name for these 3. Or use `matched` for insert and `unmatched` for update/patch/delete. I am open to suggestions if anyone feels strongly against the current scheme.\r\n\r\n- In https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5588#issuecomment-1025599455, @mgirlich mentioned the possibility of `rows_insert(conflict = \"insert\")` to insert the `y` rows anyways even if there are conflicts, but this felt too similar to `bind_rows()` to me, so I left it out (i.e. it would always insert the `y` rows, no matter what, which is basically just binding the rows together after validating that the `by` columns exist in both inputs). I think we could consider adding it later if people ask for it.\r\n\r\n- I've used a default of `\"error\"` because that is what the current behavior is, and it feels reasonable to opt in to this more lax behavior.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6203/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #> "body": "See below for a reprex for selecting a column that doesn't exist:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(x = 1:2, y = 3:4)\r\ndf\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 2\r\n#>       x     y\r\n#>   <int> <int>\r\n#> 1     1     3\r\n#> 2     2     4\r\ndf %>% select(z)\r\n#> Error in `stop_subscript()`:\r\n#> ! Can't subset columns that don't exist.\r\n#> x Column `z` doesn't exist.\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-02-27 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI think <- data.frame(x = rep(1:5, 3))\n\n# works\nlibrary(tidyverse)\ndf %>%\n  filter(x %in% sample(unique(x), size = 2, replace = FALSE))\n\n# does not work\ndf %>%\n  slice_sample(???)\n```", #> #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "mutate + recode on a character column is much slower (40x) than the same operation on a factor column,\r\neven compared to as.character(recode(factor(...),....)) \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(microbenchmark)\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\nl50 <- c(letters[1:25], LETTERS[1:25])\r\nn <- 1000000\r\n\r\nat <- tibble(\r\n  id  = seq(1, n),\r\n  str = rep(l50, n/50)\r\n)\r\n\r\nrecode_list <- as.list(setNames(str_c(\"xxx\", l50), l50))\r\n\r\nmicrobenchmark(\r\n  recode_char     = at %>% mutate(str = recode(str, !!!recode_list)),\r\n  recode_fct      = at %>% mutate(str = recode(factor(str), !!!recode_list)),\r\n  recode_fct_char = at %>% mutate(str = as.character(recode(factor(str), !!!recode_list))),\r\n  times = 10\r\n)\r\n```\r\n![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17407796/155575938-2eaee285-c425-404d-9eea-710096a9a70f.png)", #>     "reactions": { #> #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Say I have a list filter functions that I want to run against a data frame. A natural way to do this would be to use `filter(if_all(...))`. This gives an error when you invoke `cur_column()` inside `if_all(...)`.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\ncriteria <- list(\r\n    Species = \\(.x) paste(.x) < \"v\",\r\n    Petal.Width = \\(.x) .x < .3\r\n)\r\n\r\n# Error: cur_column() demands to be called inside across()\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    )\r\n#> Error in `filter()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = criteria[[cur_column()]](Species) &\r\n#>   ...`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `cur_column()`:\r\n#> ! Must be used inside `across()`.\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever, if I simply add extra parentheses around the `if_all(...)`, everything works:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\n# OK: extra parens around (if_all(...cur_column()...))\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        (if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        ))\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf I use `across(...)` instead of `if_all(...)`, it works without extra parentheses but this is deprecated. Fixing the warning was how I discovered this issue.\r\n\r\n----\r\nFull reprex.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\n\r\ncriteria <- list(\r\n    Species = \\(.x) paste(.x) < \"v\",\r\n    Petal.Width = \\(.x) .x < .3\r\n)\r\n\r\n# Error: cur_column() demands to be called inside across()\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    )\r\n#> Error in `filter()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = criteria[[cur_column()]](Species) &\r\n#>   ...`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `cur_column()`:\r\n#> ! Must be used inside `across()`.\r\n\r\n# OK: extra parens around (if_all(...cur_column()...))\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        (if_all(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        ))\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n\r\n# OK but deprecated\r\niris |>\r\n    filter(\r\n        across(\r\n            names(criteria),\r\n            ~ criteria[[cur_column()]](.x)\r\n        )\r\n    ) |>\r\n    with(table(Species)) # less verbose output\r\n#> Warning: Using `across()` in `filter()` is deprecated, use `if_any()` or\r\n#> `if_all()`.\r\n#> Species\r\n#>     setosa versicolor  virginica \r\n#>         34          0          0\r\n\r\nsessionInfo()\r\n#> R version 4.1.2 (2021-11-01)\r\n#> Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)\r\n#> Running under: Windows 10 x64 (build 19043)\r\n#> \r\n#> Matrix products: default\r\n#> \r\n#> locale:\r\n#> [1] LC_COLLATE=English_Australia.1252  LC_CTYPE=English_Australia.1252   \r\n#> [3] LC_MONETARY=English_Australia.1252 LC_NUMERIC=C                      \r\n#> [5] LC_TIME=English_Australia.1252    \r\n#> \r\n#> attached base packages:\r\n#> [1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n#> \r\n#> other attached packages:\r\n#> [1] dplyr_1.0.8\r\n#> \r\n#> loaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n#>  [1] pillar_1.7.0      compiler_4.1.2    highr_0.9         R.methodsS3_1.8.1\r\n#>  [5] R.utils_2.11.0    tools_4.1.2       digest_0.6.29     evaluate_0.15    \r\n#>  [9] lifecycle_1.0.1   tibble_3.1.6      R.cache_0.15.0    pkgconfig_2.0.3  \r\n#> [13] rlang_1.0.1       reprex_2.0.1      DBI_1.1.2 generics_0.1.2    fs_1.5.2          vctrs_0.3.8       tidyselect_1.1.1 \r\n#> [29] glue_1.6.1        R6_2.5.1          fansi_1.0.2       rmarkdown_2.11   \r\n#> [33] purrr_0.3.4       magrittr_2.0.2 "2022-02-15T13:46:34Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-02-15T13:46:34Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "When using a `mutate()` statement on a grouped dataframe, using the `!!` operator for a constant of an appropriate length greater than 1 throws an error in version 1.0.8, but, not using the `!!` operator works.  This is a break from previous versions.\r\n\r\nI first noticed the break moving from version 1.0.7 to 1.0.8, and, it appears it is still happening in the 1.0.8.9000.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.2'\r\n\r\ny <- c(1, 2)\r\n\r\n# works with y and !!y\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = y)\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 2\r\n#> # Groups:   x [2]\r\n#>   x     numbers\r\n#>   <chr>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1 a           1\r\n#> 2 a           2\r\n#> 3 b           1\r\n#> 4 b           2\r\n\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = !!y)\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 2\r\n#> # Groups:   x [2]\r\n#>   x     numbers\r\n#>   <chr>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1 a           1\r\n#> 2 a           2\r\n#> 3 b           1\r\n#> 4 b           2\r\n\r\ndetach(\"package:dplyr\", unload = TRUE)\r\nlibrary(dplyr, lib.loc = \"../../Rlib_trashme\")\r\n#> \r\n#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':\r\n#> \r\n#>     filter, lag\r\n#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':\r\n#> \r\n#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.8.9000'\r\npackageDescription(\"dplyr\")$RemoteSha\r\n#> [1] \"dd9a3b8be98c6e12bc15d7057e29a571ceab9215\"\r\n\r\n# works with y\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = y)\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 × 2\r\n#> # Groups:   x [2]\r\n#>   x     numbers\r\n#>   <chr>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1 a           1\r\n#> 2 a           2\r\n#> 3 b           1\r\n#> 4 b           2\r\n\r\n# does not work with !!y\r\ndata.frame(x = c(\"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\")) %>%\r\n  group_by(x) %>%\r\n  mutate(numbers = !!y)\r\n#> Error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `numbers = <dbl>`.\r\n#> Inlined constant `numbers` must be size 4 or 1, not 2.\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-02-15 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) dplyr::mutate(\r\n    new = purrr::map2(\r\n      .data$speed,\r\n      .data$dit, # wrong column name\r\n      function(x, y) {\r\n        x + y\r\n      }\r\n    )\r\n  )\r\n#> Error in `.rlang_cli_format_fallback()` at rlang/R/cnd-abort.R:596:4:\r\n#> ! Bullet names must be one of \"i\", \"x\", \"v\", \"*\", \"!\", \">\", or \" \".\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn a `browser()` session I see:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ncars |>\r\n  dplyr::mutate(\r\n    new = purrr::map2(\r\n      .data$speed,\r\n      .data$dit, # wrong column name\r\n      function(x, y) {\r\n        x + y\r\n      }\r\n    )\r\n  )\r\n\r\nmessage\r\n#>                         \"Problem with `mutate()` column `new`.\"\r\n#>                                                              i1\r\n#> \"`new = purrr::map2(.data$speed, .data$dit, function(x, y) {`.\"\r\n#>                                                              i2\r\n#>                                            \"`new =     x + y`.\"\r\n#>                                                              i3\r\n#>                                                   \"`new = })`.\"\r\n#>                                                               x\r\n#>             \"\\033[1m\\033[22mColumn `dit` not found in `.data`.\"\r\n\r\nnames(message)\r\n#> [1] \"\"   \"i1\" \"i2\" \"i3\" \"x\"\r\n```\r\n\r\nNot sure the multi-line deparsing is expected here.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6186/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #>       "laugh": 0, #>       "hooray": 0, #>       "confused": 0, #>       "heart": 0, #>       "rocket": 0, #>       "eyes": 0 #>     }, #>     "timeline_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6186/timeline", #>     "performed_via_github_app": {} #>   } #> ]   ## Automatic pagination users <- gh("/users", .limit = 50) length(users) #> [1] 50 if (FALSE) { ## Access developer preview of Licenses API (in preview as of 2015-09-24) gh("/licenses") # used to error code 415 gh("/licenses", .accept = "application/vnd.github.drax-preview+json") } if (FALSE) { ## Access Github Enterprise API ## Use GITHUB_API_URL environment variable to change the default. gh("/user/repos", type = "public", .api_url = "https://github.foobar.edu/api/v3") } if (FALSE) { ## Use I() to force body part to be sent as an array, even if length 1 ## This works whether assignees has length 1 or > 1 assignees <- "gh_user" assignees <- c("gh_user1", "gh_user2") gh("PATCH /repos/OWNER/REPO/issues/1", assignees = I(assignees)) } if (FALSE) { ## There are two ways to send JSON data. One is that you supply one or ## more objects that will be converted to JSON automatically via ## jsonlite::toJSON(). In this case sometimes you need to use ## jsonlite::unbox() because fromJSON() creates lists from scalar vectors ## by default. The Content-Type header is automatically added in this ## case. For example this request turns on GitHub Pages, using this ## API: https://docs.github.com/v3/repos/pages/#enable-a-pages-site  gh::gh(   "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",   owner = "gaborcsardi",   repo = "playground",   source = list(     branch = jsonlite::unbox("master"),     path = jsonlite::unbox("/docs")   ),   .send_headers = c(Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json") )  ## The second way is to handle the JSON encoding manually, and supply it ## as a raw vector in an unnamed argument, and also a Content-Type header:  body <- '{ "source": { "branch": "master", "path": "/docs" } }' gh::gh(   "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",   owner = "gaborcsardi",   repo = "playground",   charToRaw(body),   .send_headers = c(     Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json",     "Content-Type" = "application/json"   ) ) }

what: Return the local user's GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT) — gh_token
title: Return the local user's GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT) — gh_token
text: gh can find personal access token (PAT) via gh_token(), includes PAT requests. requests succeed without PAT, many require PAT prove request authorized specific GitHub user. PAT also helps rate limiting. gh use casual, want PAT. gh calls gitcreds::gitcreds_get() api_url, checks session environment variables local Git credential store PAT appropriate api_url. Therefore, previously used PAT , e.g., command line Git, gh may retrieve re-use . can call gitcreds::gitcreds_get() directly, , want see found specific URL. matching PAT found, gitcreds::gitcreds_get() errors, whereas gh_token() , instead, returns "". See GitHub's documentation Creating personal access token, use usethis::create_github_token() guided experience, including pre-selection recommended scopes. PAT, can use gitcreds::gitcreds_set() add Git credential store. point , gh (via gitcreds::gitcreds_get()) able find without effort part.

title: gh 1.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-30 gh now shows correct number records progress bar paginating (#147). New .params argument gh() make easier pass parameters programmatically (#140).

title: gh 1.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-01 Token validation accounts new format announced 2021-03-04 implemented 2021-04-01 (#148, @fmichonneau).

title: gh 1.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-27 gh_gql() now passes arguments gh() (#124). gh now handles responses pagination better, tries properly merge (#136, @rundel). gh can retrieve PAT Git credential store, lookup based targeted API URL. now uses gitcreds package. environment variables consulted URL-specific GitHub PATs changed. “https://api.github.com”: GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_COM now, instead GITHUB_PAT_API_GITHUB_COM “https://github.acme.com/api/v3”: GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_ACME_COM now, instead GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_ACME_COM_API_V3 See documentation gitcreds package details. keyring package longer used, favor Git credential store. documentation GitHub REST API moved https://docs.github.com/rest endpoints now documented using URI template style RFC 6570: Old: GET /repos/:owner/:repo/issues New: GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/issues gh accepts prioritizes new style. However, still parameter substitution old style. Fixed error occurred calling gh() .progress = FALSE (@gadenbuie, #115). gh() accepts named NA parameters destined request body (#139).

title: gh 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-01-24 Raw responses GitHub now returned raw vector. Responses may written disk providing path .destfile argument. gh now sets .Last.error error object uncaught error, .Last.error.trace stack trace error. gh() now silently drops named NULL parameters, throws error named NA parameters (#21, #84). gh() now returns better values empty responses, typically empty lists dictionaries (#66). gh() now .accept argument make easier set Accept HTTP header (#91). New gh_gql() function make easier work GitHub GraphQL API. gh now supports separate personal access tokens GitHub Enterprise sites. See ?gh_token details. gh now supports storing GitHub personal access tokens (PAT) system keyring, via keyring package. See ?gh_token details. gh() can now POST raw data, allows adding assets releases (#56).

title: gh 1.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2017-07-16 First public release.
